Chapter 3

$y'' = f(y', y, t)$
Requires $y_0$ and $y'_0$

Further, we can have $y''' = f(t,y,y',y'')$

Column vectors
$\left[\begin{matrix} a \\ b \end{matrix}\right]$ (better for non-spatial vectors)

Matrix
$\left[\begin{matrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{matrix}\right]$ is shorthand for linear systems

Example

$\begin{align} 2a + 3b &= -1 \\ a - b &= 2 \end{align}$

Can be written as: $\left[\begin{matrix} 2 & 3 \\ 1 & -1 \end{matrix}\right]\left[\begin{matrix} a \\ b \end{matrix}\right] = \left[\begin{matrix} -1 \\ 2 \end{matrix}\right]$, solutions of which solve the system.

Consider it like the dot product (Matrix $\times$ Vector):
$$\left[\begin{matrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{matrix}\right]\left[\begin{matrix} e \\ f \end{matrix}\right] = \left[\begin{matrix} ae + bf \\ ce + df \end{matrix}\right]$$

Matrix $\times$ Matrix
$$\left[\begin{matrix} A \end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix} v_1 & v_2 & v_3 \end{matrix}\right] = \left[\begin{matrix} Av_1 & Av_2 & Av_3 \end{matrix}\right]$$
for $v_i$ is a column vector, $A$ is a matrix, and $Av_i$ denotes the column vector obtained by multiplication

The problem boils down into
$$Ax = b$$
for matrix $A$ and column vector $x,b$. Solve for $x$ is simply matrix division, i.e.,
$$x = b/A = A^{-1}b$$

Find $B$ such that $BA$ is $\left[\begin{matrix} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{matrix}\right]$, called the identity matrix.
Then
$$BAx = x = Bb$$
i.e., $B = A^{-1}$.

$$A^{-1} = \left[\begin{matrix} a & b \\ c & d\end{matrix}\right]^{-1} = \frac 1 {ad - bc} \left[\begin{matrix} d & -b \\ -c & a\end{matrix}\right] = \frac 1 {\det(A)} \left[\begin{matrix} d & -b \\ -c & a\end{matrix}\right]$$

N.B., matrix multiplication is NOT commutative.



Now we are ready to tackle $y'' + ay' + by = 0$, the simplest second order ODE.
Guess (educated): $y(t) = e^{rt}$, then $y'(t) = ry(t)$ and $y''(t) = r^2y(t)$.
So, $r^2y + ary + by = 0$, which holds only for $r^2 + ar + b = 0$. Solve, giving two solutions.
